This is not the answer at all that Anton Petrov gave on the Earth's crust.  I don't think this is at all a good explanation of the earth's crust.  The Earth's crust's primary component of the upper crust is mainly made of Olivine. Olivine under greater and greater pressures suddenly changes from one mineral to another.  During these sudden changes, Olivine can crack and where most of our earthquakes come from. The earth's crust is also filled with graphite from Ancheint life, and it is these deposits that allow the earth's crust to move.  It would be more prudent to think of the Earth's Crust as a few giant slabs of Asphalt sliding past one another.  Asphalt is not one solid piece of rock it is thousands and millions of pieces all stuck together and with the tremendous amount of pressure these pieces crack and move very very slowly.  It's the Olivine that cracks and breaks with tremendous pressure that causes the majority of earthquakes because it's too hard to just crack and move as the rest does yet when it suddenly changes from Olivine to Wadesleyite to Ringwoodite to Periclase, etc (just a loose example) we get the cracks, breaks, and earthquakes which allow the crust to keep moving.  Unlike other planets that do not have plate tectonics, their crust is too hard to crack and move.

I'm a painter of houses, so I have been lucky enough in my life to be high on ladders (and solvents) while inspecting old glass windows very carefully. I know that if the glass is wider then they are glazed with the wider side down, which make sense.

I also know that really old window glass was made flat from a large ball of molten glass being spun (this glass distinctively has stretched out bubbles in it and is a little wavy up close) into a large circle, then the rectangle for the window was snapped out of that big circle.

That glass circle is thicker in the middle, so the rectangles have a thick corner or bottom. An really good example is in muntined windows (when they are divided into a lot of lights) because these are cut sometimes (for effect I think) from the parts between the bigger rectangles so they have distortions that are more distinct and bubbles that are stretched in unexpected directions.

Waves can't propagate through liquid? Then I guess that sound waves don't propagate through water and travel exponentially farther than through air, huh? Oh, wait; that's wrong. It's been a mainstay fact of science for a long, long, long time that liquids propagate vibrations/waves better than solids and gases since liquids are neither compressible nor excessively rigid, allowing waves to travel through them far more easily and for far-greater distances. The loosely-arranged molecules of liquids require less energy to transfer waves from particle to particle and lose less energy as waves transfer from particle to particle. After all, that's only been proven by film footage of the construction of Hoover Dam when workers used machinery to send vibrating waves into the yet-liquid, unset concrete to allow dispersed air in the concrete to come out, thus making for a stronger alignment of molecules in the hardened concrete. This certainly would've never worked after having allowed the aerated concrete to set into a completely-solid state beforehand. Tell me again how liquids propagate waves worse than solids. I'd love see any sort of physical evidence that disproves what is currently available.

maybe the reason the old stained glass is thicker towards the bottom is over those many centuries, they have been exposed to enough heat to slowly return a few molecules of the glass to a liquid state here and there. (just like how water doesn't have to reach boiling point to have some evaporate, just needs enough energy in a handful of molecules for it to break away from the rest of the liquid and turn into a gas). particularly with the high lead volume in old stained glass, a nearby fire (like a bonfire or the like) could potentially cause a miniscule shift towards liquid state from the heat, and over centuries having even that tiny amount melt, slide down a bit before rehardening, over and over, could cause it to build up towards the bottom. The telescopes are probably more likely to be away from high heat sources, plus the glass used in telescope lenses is very likely a different composition of materials (there are a number of types of glass from different chemicals, and even the same base types made from silica primarily can have other impurities added in)

One fascinating thing is that it can be far more helpful when working with building foundations to consider the ground to be liquid, like honey, just a really really thick liquid...and if you are studying liquefaction, a not so thick liquid.

Now generally speaking, it's not a liquid, but unless you go deep you aren't usually dealing with solid rock, and the particles of dirt, or clay, or sand, slide past each other somewhat like the atoms in a bucket of water.

By extension, designing good foundations can feel very much like designing a boat. There's even an analogous force to buoyancy, soil heave!

There is also another way to call the glass: "solid solution". It's a kind of oxymoron. In metallurgy we have another solid solution: tempered steel. Microscopy of samples shows clearly a different structure than a non treated steel. The assertion that over time we could see that the glass will flow is not telling enough, or the theory is incomplete. It depends also of other factors: temperature and transformation. There is transformation(s) since according the temperature atoms are forming different arrangements or structures (atomic lattices). The quantity of transformations change according the time of temperature exposure. Structure changes do not happen in a snap. It requests thermal energy. In metallurgy we say structures of  steels depend on  these 3 factors, and we have T-T-T diagrams (temperature, time, transformation) . Therefore, metallurgists follow these diagrams according the quality of steel they want to get. Metallurgy lab sessions are still very vivid in my memory. It was fascinating to observe ferrous alloys transformations and their mechanical properties changing.

Okay, you can make that argument, but I mean it isn't exactly fair to make the argument that because the molecules shifted towards the Earth that it's actually liquid. All things on this Earth will fall to its center if it isn't lighter than its own pull, some more obvious than others, and this is a slippery slope for you to be dancing upon. Frankly, because we know that glass started its life as silicate - like from a beach - we should be starting with the benefit of a doubt. That is, 'Glass was formed via temporary change to a solid to make it more fluid until it cooled back into a solid material, albeit largly different from its original form.', because this is true. It was formed INTO a liquid by heat, but that is not a sustainable thing at room remperature, like water or even the pitch. It's not going to flow down my sill and onto the floor, not ever, because it will break first, which is a characteristic of a solid. What we have here is something that stuck very firmly in my mind in college: The stacking of molecules. Liquid molecules often in motion, solids much less so, and the more efficiently stacked the molecules are, the more solid that solid IS. Glass is not liquid like any other liquid you could mention, including a lava flow that is so slow that it's become like a moving heated crust. It's an inefficiently-stacked solid.

Rheidity: the time over which a solid behaves like a liquid. The rheidity of ice, salt, gypsum and serpentine are respectively of the order of a fortnight, a year, ten years and ten thousand years. Glaciers, salt domes, gypsum extrusions, and post-magmatic re-intrusion of serpentine are examples of rheid behaviour. Geological and astronomical evidence indicates that the rheidity of the mantle of the earth varies from tens of thousands of years at the top to hundreds of years at the base. Since tectonic loads are maintained from ten thousand to ten million years, the mantle of the earth behaves as a fluid for all geotectonic phenomena. The rheidity of the crust varies from 105 to 109 years, and hence the crust behaves as a solid for many tectonic processes.

In the early history of glass, windows were made by gatherings large glob of glass on the end of a rod. You then rolled the rod to create a disc of glass. Spinning the disc till it was about 4 feet in diameter then allowing the glass to cool. Squares were then cut from the disc. Never the hub of the disc the glass is much thicker, so the glazier would grind a flange from both sides so that the glass would fit in the frame and would allow putty to hold it in the frame. This gave the appearance of  the glass flowing down to flow over the frame. You can judge this glass's age by how thick the edge is and the number of air bubbles present. This technique was used until the mid 19'th century when the glass was blown into a steel mold to make a cylinder then the top and bottom of the bottle shape were cut off and it was scored down one side . This scored cylinder was the put into an annealing oven to soften and lay flat.

Window panes were made different in the past.
Nowadays we have float glass, where molten glass is poured on molten tin.
In the old days I read they had pulled glass.
A rod is put in molten glass over it's entire length, and then moved upward carefully.
The glass sticks to the rod like soapy water, and gets hard.
The bottom gets thicker, because of the glass cooling off fast.
(Glass doesn't have a precise melting point)
When they put the pane into a window, they would put the thicker part at the bottom,
otherwise the thin part would have support most of the weight.
Glass is a fluid, not a liquid.

Almost everyone is familiar with the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. However, what is known to far fewer people is the Heisenberg Certainty Principle (it was actually written with the help of a lawyer, Dr. Murphy). In it, they talk about how the observer effect prevents kettles from boiling, grass from growing, paint from drying, or a drop of pitch from dropping. The scientist you mentioned in the video was already aware of Murphy's Law/ Heisenberg's Certainty Principle, so he didn't miss the pitch dropping by accident. Rather, it was a deliberate act, done to allow the physical laws to override the observer effect...


Ps: If you couldn't already tell, there is no such thing as the Heisenberg Certainty Principle, though there really is a thing called Murphy's Law ("if something can go wrong, it will"). In any case, if the origin story of the aphorism and it's creator is accurate, then it's highly unlikely that Capt. A. Murphy ever met Werner Heisenberg (even if we knew the velocity of... never mind). It's meant to be a joke that I expect few people will get and fewer still will find funny...

In fact glass is neither a liquid nor a solid, it's glassy which is its own state of matter. Water can also be made glassy by freezing it very rapidly bellow -150 degrees centigrade, in which case it stops flowing and locks anything in it, but it also isn't exactly a solid either. It has been shown that glassy water and an amorphous water solid are two different states. A glassy state is a kinetically trapped liquid that is too cold to flow yet also doesn't have enough energy to pass the kinetic barrier and solidify.
As much as I love this type of videos, it makes me sad when they spread misinformation. I personally don't have a problem with people calling glass a liquid since it does have some of the properties of a liquid.

Source: I have a PhD in chemistry and some experience on working with these states.

It's all a jumble of terminology.
I think that the conditions exist for us to be prejudiced when we observe certain interactions. We often place observations into a false dichotomy because of what we expect, when in fact the character of what we are actually observing might be much more nuanced and defiant to our definitions. In a way it's almost an error of language, more so than an error of human understanding. In observing a scientific phenomenon that has yet to be in context with the "common" knowledge of the public, a scientist often uses words that are still very much too broad to really capture the essence of what is taking place, and so it really reflects on the curiosity of individuals. So much of science is simply compared to common knowledge, as a way of making it understandable, when any particular event is nearly always different from the others even if only in a small way. It's just always been so fascinating the level of development that certain sciences have evolved, and how the learning curves of the discipline are still very much completely unknown (to my knowledge). We all assume that there's a point beyond which any discovery is not really a huge step forward any longer. A point at which we essentially have "understood" what is in front of us. I liken this discussion to Plato's cave analogy, where but the exiting of one cave is only really the entry into a larger one, which serves only to lessen one's ignorance, rather than to earnestly increase one's knowledge.

To my mind it appears that the difficulty is only imaginary and not real. Rigidity and plasticity are not absolute terms but relative, and all solids are in fact both rigid and plastic. The apparent contrast between the two properties belongs to the laboratory and to those phenomena of nature involving small masses and small forces. When great masses and great forces are involved, as for example in the making of continents and mountain chains, the distinction loses value. The phenomena of mountain structure demonstrate that under sufficient strains great bodies of rock both bend and flow.
Grove Karl Gilbert, 1892

Excellent episode. It seems as though the labels we apply to things are only metaphors for our own understanding, at best. The lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary of the Earth defines a sudden drop in shear velocity in the earth. Why? The upper mantle contains more volatile content (hydrous phases) as well as an increase in partial melt which HAS to be a lower viscosity than surrounding mantle to move up and make our volcanoes and plutons (e.g. the Sierras). Furthermore, the LAB also defines a point within the earth where the primary mode of heat transfer switches from conduction in the lithosphere to convection in the mantle, convention being the transport of heat through a liquid.

You're video isn't entirely correct nor entirely false, the S-wave shadow zone does define a body (the core) that cannot transport shear energy which makes the core undeniably liquid (I recall a viscosity similar to water from my undergrad), but there are other essential qualities like the transport of heat and the relative speed of shear energy among many MANY others that can define a liquid in the context of earth (e.g. seismic anisotropy).

I would suggest maybe clearly defining a liquid when talking about the earth's bulk compositional phases before you take on a subject like this that's been filled with controversy since the Cold War (the birth of modern seismology). Perhaps defining the marked point that you define as a solid as the point where we have left the upper mantle, that being the upslope in shear velocity following the LAB as well as the massive drop in seismic anisotropy as well, called the lower mantle.

In the old days, there were only a couple of ways to make flat glass, like the glass used for stained glass windows in old European churches. The most common way was to melt a large glob of glass, pick it up with a pipe (or pole) and twirl it like you'd spin a pizza. After a while the centrifugal force would flatten it out enough that, when cooled, they could cut it up and use it. But like pancake batter flowing on a griddle, it was always thicker in the middle, and thinner as it went outward. So the glaziers would usually put the thicker edge of each piece on the bottom, as this was more stable.

PS - The center piece of the glass would still have some of original glob on it, making it clear enough for letting light through but too distorted to see through. These pieces were commonly used by poor people as window glass. (Especially common in early American homes.)

While it is interesting to consider different states of matter as more or less the same but with relative differences, that kind of undermines the fact that substances have very specific freezing/melting and boiling points. For example, with boiling water, the liquid portion of the water will remain at exactly 100 degrees Celsius until its heat source stops or until all the liquid water has evaporated into the vapor state (steam.) This pretty much applies to all substances, and shows that the definitions of these states are in fact concrete and have distinguishable effects.

Is glass a liquid?
Short answer, no.
Long answer, nooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo

I believe the issue of whether glass is a liquid is based on the fact that glass has a glass transition temperature Tg - above this point, the volume expansion per increase in unit temperature is far higher than below the Tg, yet remains amorphous in nature - no phase change. As the Tg occurs over a range (compared with melt temperature Tm), and the fact that at the Tg there is no decrease in energy flux over temperature increase (indicating no phase change), the conclusion is that glass is, just like pitch and the molten magma, a liquid with an incredibly high viscosity. Just because we are unable to view it as flowing, it does not mean it is a solid.

Further to this, when glass is heated to temperatures below Tg, an energy flux versus increase in temperature will show the glass will NOT change phase, even though it begins to flow. If a solid were to flow, it MUST undergo a phase transition at the Tm, which would be reflected in an energy flux versus temperature plot. As glass will flow at higher temperatures without undergoing phase change, the conclusion is it is indeed a liquid, and not a solid. Pitch may seem like a solid to a mayfly, but objectively it remains a liquid.

This episodes brings to mind when I first learned the term "viscosity" and what it meant.

I was a textile silk screen imprinter. We worked with plastisol inks. Much of the nuances to making all of those concert tee shirt icons of pop culture throughout the 70's and 80's revolved around how well one could change, and manipulate the viscosity of those inks to get them to perform on dark fabrics. That was my specific specialty.

Interesting note on plastisol inks: they remained pliable and wet until reaching a specific temperature for a specific amount of time which they then would "cure" and adhere to the fabric without washing or flaking off. So in some ways. those inks are similar to glass.
